scene.title: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.

scene-body.stagedir: Enter Poet, Painter, Jeweller, Merchant, and others, at several doors

speech.speaker: Poet
speech.line: Good day, sir.

speech.speaker: Painter
speech.line: I am glad you're well.

speech.speaker: Poet
speech.line: I have not seen you long: how goes the world?

speech.speaker: Painter
speech.line: It wears, sir, as it grows.

speech.speaker: Poet
speech.line: Ay, that's well known:
But what particular rarity? what strange,
Which manifold record not matches? See,
Magic of bounty! all these spirits thy power
Hath conjured to attend. I know the merchant.

speech.speaker: Painter
speech.line: I know them both; th' other's a jeweller.

speech.speaker: Merchant
speech.line: O, 'tis a worthy lord.

speech.speaker: Jeweller
speech.line: Nay, that's most fix'd.

speech.speaker: Merchant
speech.line: A most incomparable man, breathed, as it were,
To an untirable and continuate goodness:
He passes.

speech.speaker: Jeweller:
speech.line: I have a jewel here--

speech.speaker: Merchant
speech.line: O, pray, let's see't: for the Lord Timon, sir?

speech.speaker: Jeweller:
speech.line: If he will touch the estimate: but, for that--

speech.speaker: Poet
speech.line: Reciting to himself 'When we for recompense have
praised the vile,
It stains the glory in that happy verse
Which aptly sings the good.'

speech.speaker: Merchant
speech.line: 'Tis a good form.

speech.speaker: Jeweller
speech.line: And rich: here is a water, look ye.

speech.speaker: Painter
speech.line: You are rapt, sir, in some work, some dedication
To the great lord.

speech.speaker: Poet
speech.line: A thing slipp'd idly from me.
Our poesy is as a gum, which oozes
From whence 'tis nourish'd: the fire i' the flint
Shows not till it be struck; our gentle flame
Provokes itself and like the current flies
Each bound it chafes. What have you there?

speech.speaker: Painter
speech.line: A picture, sir. When comes your book forth?

speech.speaker: Poet
speech.line: Upon the heels of my presentment, sir.
Let's see your piece.

speech.speaker: Painter
speech.line: 'Tis a good piece.

speech.speaker: Poet
speech.line: So 'tis: this comes off well and excellent.

speech.speaker: Painter
speech.line: Indifferent.

speech.speaker: Poet
speech.line: Admirable: how this grace
Speaks his own standing! what a mental power
This eye shoots forth! how big imagination
Moves in this lip! to the dumbness of the gesture
One might interpret.

speech.speaker: Painter
speech.line: It is a pretty mocking of the life.
Here is a touch; is't good?

speech.speaker: Poet
speech.line: I will say of it,
It tutors nature: artificial strife
Lives in these touches, livelier than life.

scene-body.stagedir: Enter certain Senators, and pass over

speech.speaker: Painter
speech.line: How this lord is follow'd!

speech.speaker: Poet
speech.line: The senators of Athens: happy man!

speech.speaker: Painter
speech.line: Look, more!

speech.speaker: Poet
speech.line: You see this confluence, this great flood
of visitors.
I have, in this rough work, shaped out a man,
Whom this beneath world doth embrace and hug
With amplest entertainment: my free drift
Halts not particularly, but moves itself
In a wide sea of wax: no levell'd malice
Infects one comma in the course I hold;
But flies an eagle flight, bold and forth on,
Leaving no tract behind.

speech.speaker: Painter
speech.line: How shall I understand you?

speech.speaker: Poet
speech.line: I will unbolt to you.
You see how all conditions, how all minds,
As well of glib and slippery creatures as
Of grave and austere quality, tender down
Their services to Lord Timon: his large fortune
Upon his good and gracious nature hanging
Subdues and properties to his love and tendance
All sorts of hearts; yea, from the glass-faced flatterer
To Apemantus, that few things loves better
Than to abhor himself: even he drops down
The knee before him, and returns in peace
Most rich in Timon's nod.

speech.speaker: Painter
speech.line: I saw them speak together.

speech.speaker: Poet
speech.line: Sir, I have upon a high and pleasant hill
Feign'd Fortune to be throned: the base o' the mount
Is rank'd with all deserts, all kind of natures,
That labour on the bosom of this sphere
To propagate their states: amongst them all,
Whose eyes are on this sovereign lady fix'd,
One do I personate of Lord Timon's frame,
Whom Fortune with her ivory hand wafts to her;
Whose present grace to present slaves and servants
Translates his rivals.

speech.speaker: Painter
speech.line: 'Tis conceived to scope.
This throne, this Fortune, and this hill, methinks,
With one man beckon'd from the rest below,
Bowing his head against the sleepy mount
To climb his happiness, would be well express'd
In our condition.

speech.speaker: Poet
speech.line: Nay, sir, but hear me on.
All those which were his fellows but of late,
Some better than his value, on the moment
Follow his strides, his lobbies fill with tendance,
Rain sacrificial whisperings in his ear,
Make sacred even his stirrup, and through him
Drink the free air.

speech.speaker: Painter
speech.line: Ay, marry, what of these?

speech.speaker: Poet
speech.line: When Fortune in her shift and change of mood
Spurns down her late beloved, all his dependants
Which labour'd after him to the mountain's top
Even on their knees and hands, let him slip down,
Not one accompanying his declining foot.

speech.speaker: Painter
speech.line: 'Tis common:
A thousand moral paintings I can show
That shall demonstrate these quick blows of Fortune's
More pregnantly than words. Yet you do well
To show Lord Timon that mean eyes have seen
The foot above the head.

scene-body.stagedir: Trumpets sound. Enter TIMON, addressing himself courteously to every suitor; a Messenger from VENTIDIUS talking with him; LUCILIUS and other servants following

speech.speaker: TIMON
speech.line: Imprison'd is he, say you?

speech.speaker: Messenger
speech.line: Ay, my good lord: five talents is his debt,
His means most short, his creditors most strait:
Your honourable letter he desires
To those have shut him up; which failing,
Periods his comfort.

speech.speaker: TIMON
speech.line: Noble Ventidius! Well;
I am not of that feather to shake off
My friend when he must need me. I do know him
A gentleman that well deserves a help:
Which he shall have: I'll pay the debt,
and free him.

speech.speaker: Messenger
speech.line: Your lordship ever binds him.

speech.speaker: TIMON
speech.line: Commend me to him: I will send his ransom;
And being enfranchised, bid him come to me.
'Tis not enough to help the feeble up,
But to support him after. Fare you well.

speech.speaker: Messenger
speech.line: All happiness to your honour!

speech.speaker: Old Athenian
speech.line: Lord Timon, hear me speak.

speech.speaker: TIMON
speech.line: Freely, good father.

speech.speaker: Old Athenian
speech.line: Thou hast a servant named Lucilius.

speech.speaker: TIMON
speech.line: I have so: what of him?

speech.speaker: Old Athenian
speech.line: Most noble Timon, call the man before thee.

speech.speaker: TIMON
speech.line: Attends he here, or no? Lucilius!

speech.speaker: LUCILIUS
speech.line: Here, at your lordship's service.

speech.speaker: Old Athenian
speech.line: This fellow here, Lord Timon, this thy creature,
By night frequents my house. I am a man
That from my first have been inclined to thrift;
And my estate deserves an heir more raised
Than one which holds a trencher.

speech.speaker: TIMON
speech.line: Well; what further?

speech.speaker: Old Athenian
speech.line: One only daughter have I, no kin else,
On whom I may confer what I have got:
The maid is fair, o' the youngest for a bride,
And I have bred her at my dearest cost
In qualities of the best. This man of thine
Attempts her love: I prithee, noble lord,
Join with me to forbid him her resort;
Myself have spoke in vain.

speech.speaker: TIMON
speech.line: The man is honest.

speech.speaker: Old Athenian
speech.line: Therefore he will be, Timon:
His honesty rewards him in itself;
It must not bear my daughter.

speech.speaker: TIMON
speech.line: Does she love him?

speech.speaker: Old Athenian
speech.line: She is young and apt:
Our own precedent passions do instruct us
What levity's in youth.

speech.speaker: TIMON
speech.line: To LUCILIUS Love you the maid?

speech.speaker: LUCILIUS
speech.line: Ay, my good lord, and she accepts of it.

speech.speaker: Old Athenian
speech.line: If in her marriage my consent be missing,
I call the gods to witness, I will choose
Mine heir from forth the beggars of the world,
And dispossess her all.

speech.speaker: TIMON
speech.line: How shall she be endow'd,
if she be mated with an equal husband?

speech.speaker: Old Athenian
speech.line: Three talents on the present; in future, all.

speech.speaker: TIMON
speech.line: This gentleman of mine hath served me long:
To build his fortune I will strain a little,
For 'tis a bond in men. Give him thy daughter:
What you bestow, in him I'll counterpoise,
And make him weigh with her.

speech.speaker: Old Athenian
speech.line: Most noble lord,
Pawn me to this your honour, she is his.

speech.speaker: TIMON
speech.line: My hand to thee; mine honour on my promise.

speech.speaker: LUCILIUS
speech.line: Humbly I thank your lordship: never may
The state or fortune fall into my keeping,
Which is not owed to you!

speech.speaker: Poet
speech.line: Vouchsafe my labour, and long live your lordship!

speech.speaker: TIMON
speech.line: I thank you; you shall hear from me anon:
Go not away. What have you there, my friend?

speech.speaker: Painter
speech.line: A piece of painting, which I do beseech
Your lordship to accept.

speech.speaker: TIMON
speech.line: Painting is welcome.
The painting is almost the natural man;
or since dishonour traffics with man's nature,
He is but outside: these pencill'd figures are
Even such as they give out. I like your work;
And you shall find I like it: wait attendance
Till you hear further from me.

speech.speaker: Painter
speech.line: The gods preserve ye!

speech.speaker: TIMON
speech.line: Well fare you, gentleman: give me your hand;
We must needs dine together. Sir, your jewel
Hath suffer'd under praise.

speech.speaker: Jeweller
speech.line: What, my lord! dispraise?

speech.speaker: TIMON
speech.line: A more satiety of commendations.
If I should pay you for't as 'tis extoll'd,
It would unclew me quite.

speech.speaker: Jeweller
speech.line: My lord, 'tis rated
As those which sell would give: but you well know,
Things of like value differing in the owners
Are prized by their masters: believe't, dear lord,
You mend the jewel by the wearing it.

speech.speaker: TIMON
speech.line: Well mock'd.

speech.speaker: Merchant
speech.line: No, my good lord; he speaks the common tongue,
Which all men speak with him.

speech.speaker: TIMON
speech.line: Look, who comes here: will you be chid?

speech.speaker: Jeweller
speech.line: We'll bear, with your lordship.

speech.speaker: Merchant
speech.line: He'll spare none.

speech.speaker: TIMON
speech.line: Good morrow to thee, gentle Apemantus!

speech.speaker: APEMANTUS
speech.line: Till I be gentle, stay thou for thy good morrow;
When thou art Timon's dog, and these knaves honest.

speech.speaker: TIMON
speech.line: Why dost thou call them knaves? thou know'st them not.

speech.speaker: APEMANTUS
speech.line: Are they not Athenians?

speech.speaker: TIMON
speech.line: Yes.

speech.speaker: APEMANTUS
speech.line: Then I repent not.

speech.speaker: Jeweller
speech.line: You know me, Apemantus?

speech.speaker: APEMANTUS
speech.line: Thou know'st I do: I call'd thee by thy name.

speech.speaker: TIMON
speech.line: Thou art proud, Apemantus.

speech.speaker: APEMANTUS
speech.line: Of nothing so much as that I am not like Timon.

speech.speaker: TIMON
speech.line: Whither art going?

speech.speaker: APEMANTUS
speech.line: To knock out an honest Athenian's brains.

speech.speaker: TIMON
speech.line: That's a deed thou'lt die for.

speech.speaker: APEMANTUS
speech.line: Right, if doing nothing be death by the law.

speech.speaker: TIMON
speech.line: How likest thou this picture, Apemantus?

speech.speaker: APEMANTUS
speech.line: The best, for the innocence.

speech.speaker: TIMON
speech.line: Wrought he not well that painted it?

speech.speaker: APEMANTUS
speech.line: He wrought better that made the painter; and yet
he's but a filthy piece of work.

speech.speaker: Painter
speech.line: You're a dog.

speech.speaker: APEMANTUS
speech.line: Thy mother's of my generation: what's she, if I be a dog?

speech.speaker: TIMON
speech.line: Wilt dine with me, Apemantus?

speech.speaker: APEMANTUS
speech.line: No; I eat not lords.

speech.speaker: TIMON
speech.line: An thou shouldst, thou 'ldst anger ladies.

speech.speaker: APEMANTUS
speech.line: O, they eat lords; so they come by great bellies.

speech.speaker: TIMON
speech.line: That's a lascivious apprehension.

speech.speaker: APEMANTUS
speech.line: So thou apprehendest it: take it for thy labour.

speech.speaker: TIMON
speech.line: How dost thou like this jewel, Apemantus?

speech.speaker: APEMANTUS
speech.line: Not so well as plain-dealing, which will not cost a
man a doit.

speech.speaker: TIMON
speech.line: What dost thou think 'tis worth?

speech.speaker: APEMANTUS
speech.line: Not worth my thinking. How now, poet!

speech.speaker: Poet
speech.line: How now, philosopher!

speech.speaker: APEMANTUS
speech.line: Thou liest.

speech.speaker: Poet
speech.line: Art not one?

speech.speaker: APEMANTUS
speech.line: Yes.

speech.speaker: Poet
speech.line: Then I lie not.

speech.speaker: APEMANTUS
speech.line: Art not a poet?

speech.speaker: Poet
speech.line: Yes.

speech.speaker: APEMANTUS
speech.line: Then thou liest: look in thy last work, where thou
hast feigned him a worthy fellow.

speech.speaker: Poet
speech.line: That's not feigned; he is so.

speech.speaker: APEMANTUS
speech.line: Yes, he is worthy of thee, and to pay thee for thy
labour: he that loves to be flattered is worthy o'
the flatterer. Heavens, that I were a lord!

speech.speaker: TIMON
speech.line: What wouldst do then, Apemantus?

speech.speaker: APEMANTUS
speech.line: E'en as Apemantus does now; hate a lord with my heart.

speech.speaker: TIMON
speech.line: What, thyself?

speech.speaker: APEMANTUS
speech.line: Ay.

speech.speaker: TIMON
speech.line: Wherefore?

speech.speaker: APEMANTUS
speech.line: That I had no angry wit to be a lord.
Art not thou a merchant?

speech.speaker: Merchant
speech.line: Ay, Apemantus.

speech.speaker: APEMANTUS
speech.line: Traffic confound thee, if the gods will not!

speech.speaker: Merchant
speech.line: If traffic do it, the gods do it.

speech.speaker: APEMANTUS
speech.line: Traffic's thy god; and thy god confound thee!

speech.speaker: TIMON
speech.line: What trumpet's that?

speech.speaker: Messenger
speech.line: 'Tis Alcibiades, and some twenty horse,
All of companionship.

speech.speaker: TIMON
speech.line: Pray, entertain them; give them guide to us.
You must needs dine with me: go not you hence
Till I have thank'd you: when dinner's done,
Show me this piece. I am joyful of your sights.
Most welcome, sir!

speech.speaker: APEMANTUS
speech.line: So, so, there!
Aches contract and starve your supple joints!
That there should be small love 'mongst these
sweet knaves,
And all this courtesy! The strain of man's bred out
Into baboon and monkey.

speech.speaker: ALCIBIADES
speech.line: Sir, you have saved my longing, and I feed
Most hungerly on your sight.

speech.speaker: TIMON
speech.line: Right welcome, sir!
Ere we depart, we'll share a bounteous time
In different pleasures. Pray you, let us in.

speech.speaker: First Lord
speech.line: What time o' day is't, Apemantus?

speech.speaker: APEMANTUS
speech.line: Time to be honest.

speech.speaker: First Lord
speech.line: That time serves still.

speech.speaker: APEMANTUS
speech.line: The more accursed thou, that still omitt'st it.

speech.speaker: Second Lord
speech.line: Thou art going to Lord Timon's feast?

speech.speaker: APEMANTUS
speech.line: Ay, to see meat fill knaves and wine heat fools.

speech.speaker: Second Lord
speech.line: Fare thee well, fare thee well.

speech.speaker: APEMANTUS
speech.line: Thou art a fool to bid me farewell twice.

speech.speaker: Second Lord
speech.line: Why, Apemantus?

speech.speaker: APEMANTUS
speech.line: Shouldst have kept one to thyself, for I mean to
give thee none.

speech.speaker: First Lord
speech.line: Hang thyself!

speech.speaker: APEMANTUS
speech.line: No, I will do nothing at thy bidding: make thy
requests to thy friend.

speech.speaker: Second Lord
speech.line: Away, unpeaceable dog, or I'll spurn thee hence!

speech.speaker: APEMANTUS
speech.line: I will fly, like a dog, the heels o' the ass.

speech.speaker: First Lord
speech.line: He's opposite to humanity. Come, shall we in,
And taste Lord Timon's bounty? he outgoes
The very heart of kindness.

speech.speaker: Second Lord
speech.line: He pours it out; Plutus, the god of gold,
Is but his steward: no meed, but he repays
Sevenfold above itself; no gift to him,
But breeds the giver a return exceeding
All use of quittance.

speech.speaker: First Lord
speech.line: The noblest mind he carries
That ever govern'd man.

speech.speaker: Second Lord
speech.line: Long may he live in fortunes! Shall we in?

speech.speaker: First Lord
speech.line: I'll keep you company.

scene.title: SCENE II. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.

scene-body.stagedir: Hautboys playing loud music. A great banquet served in; FLAVIUS and others attending; then enter TIMON, ALCIBIADES, Lords, Senators, and VENTIDIUS. Then comes, dropping, after all, APEMANTUS, discontentedly, like himself

speech.speaker: VENTIDIUS
speech.line: Most honour'd Timon,
It hath pleased the gods to remember my father's age,
And call him to long peace.
He is gone happy, and has left me rich:
Then, as in grateful virtue I am bound
To your free heart, I do return those talents,
Doubled with thanks and service, from whose help
I derived liberty.

speech.speaker: TIMON
speech.line: O, by no means,
Honest Ventidius; you mistake my love:
I gave it freely ever; and there's none
Can truly say he gives, if he receives:
If our betters play at that game, we must not dare
To imitate them; faults that are rich are fair.

speech.speaker: VENTIDIUS
speech.line: A noble spirit!

speech.speaker: TIMON
speech.line: Nay, my lords,
speech.stagedir: They all stand ceremoniously looking on TIMON
speech.line: Ceremony was but devised at first
To set a gloss on faint deeds, hollow welcomes,
Recanting goodness, sorry ere 'tis shown;
But where there is true friendship, there needs none.
Pray, sit; more welcome are ye to my fortunes
Than my fortunes to me.

speech.speaker: First Lord
speech.line: My lord, we always have confess'd it.

speech.speaker: APEMANTUS
speech.line: Ho, ho, confess'd it! hang'd it, have you not?

speech.speaker: TIMON
speech.line: O, Apemantus, you are welcome.

speech.speaker: APEMANTUS
speech.line: No;
You shall not make me welcome:
I come to have thee thrust me out of doors.

speech.speaker: TIMON
speech.line: Fie, thou'rt a churl; ye've got a humour there
Does not become a man: 'tis much to blame.
They say, my lords, 'ira furor brevis est;' but yond
man is ever angry. Go, let him have a table by
himself, for he does neither affect company, nor is
he fit for't, indeed.

speech.speaker: APEMANTUS
speech.line: Let me stay at thine apperil, Timon: I come to
observe; I give thee warning on't.

speech.speaker: TIMON
speech.line: I take no heed of thee; thou'rt an Athenian,
therefore welcome: I myself would have no power;
prithee, let my meat make thee silent.

speech.speaker: APEMANTUS
speech.line: I scorn thy meat; 'twould choke me, for I should
ne'er flatter thee. O you gods, what a number of
men eat Timon, and he sees 'em not! It grieves me
to see so many dip their meat in one man's blood;
and all the madness is, he cheers them up too.
I wonder men dare trust themselves with men:
Methinks they should invite them without knives;
Good for their meat, and safer for their lives.
There's much example for't; the fellow that sits
next him now, parts bread with him, pledges the
breath of him in a divided draught, is the readiest
man to kill him: 't has been proved. If I were a
huge man, I should fear to drink at meals;
Lest they should spy my windpipe's dangerous notes:
Great men should drink with harness on their throats.

speech.speaker: TIMON
speech.line: My lord, in heart; and let the health go round.

speech.speaker: Second Lord
speech.line: Let it flow this way, my good lord.

speech.speaker: APEMANTUS
speech.line: Flow this way! A brave fellow! he keeps his tides
well. Those healths will make thee and thy state
look ill, Timon. Here's that which is too weak to
be a sinner, honest water, which ne'er left man i' the mire:
This and my food are equals; there's no odds:
Feasts are too proud to give thanks to the gods.
Apemantus' grace.
Immortal gods, I crave no pelf;
I pray for no man but myself:
Grant I may never prove so fond,
To trust man on his oath or bond;
Or a harlot, for her weeping;
Or a dog, that seems a-sleeping:
Or a keeper with my freedom;
Or my friends, if I should need 'em.
Amen. So fall to't:
Rich men sin, and I eat root.
Much good dich thy good heart, Apemantus!

speech.speaker: TIMON
speech.line: Captain Alcibiades, your heart's in the field now.

speech.speaker: ALCIBIADES
speech.line: My heart is ever at your service, my lord.

speech.speaker: TIMON
speech.line: You had rather be at a breakfast of enemies than a
dinner of friends.

speech.speaker: ALCIBIADES
speech.line: So the were bleeding-new, my lord, there's no meat
like 'em: I could wish my best friend at such a feast.

speech.speaker: APEMANTUS
speech.line: Would all those fatterers were thine enemies then,
that then thou mightst kill 'em and bid me to 'em!

speech.speaker: First Lord
speech.line: Might we but have that happiness, my lord, that you
would once use our hearts, whereby we might express
some part of our zeals, we should think ourselves
for ever perfect.

speech.speaker: TIMON
speech.line: O, no doubt, my good friends, but the gods
themselves have provided that I shall have much help
from you: how had you been my friends else? why
have you that charitable title from thousands, did
not you chiefly belong to my heart? I have told
more of you to myself than you can with modesty
speak in your own behalf; and thus far I confirm
you. O you gods, think I, what need we have any
friends, if we should ne'er have need of 'em? they
were the most needless creatures living, should we
ne'er have use for 'em, and would most resemble
sweet instruments hung up in cases that keep their
sounds to themselves. Why, I have often wished
myself poorer, that I might come nearer to you. We
are born to do benefits: and what better or
properer can we can our own than the riches of our
friends? O, what a precious comfort 'tis, to have
so many, like brothers, commanding one another's
fortunes! O joy, e'en made away ere 't can be born!
Mine eyes cannot hold out water, methinks: to
forget their faults, I drink to you.

speech.speaker: APEMANTUS
speech.line: Thou weepest to make them drink, Timon.

speech.speaker: Second Lord
speech.line: Joy had the like conception in our eyes
And at that instant like a babe sprung up.

speech.speaker: APEMANTUS
speech.line: Ho, ho! I laugh to think that babe a bastard.

speech.speaker: Third Lord
speech.line: I promise you, my lord, you moved me much.

speech.speaker: APEMANTUS
speech.line: Much!

speech.speaker: TIMON
speech.line: What means that trump?
How now?

speech.speaker: Servant
speech.line: Please you, my lord, there are certain
ladies most desirous of admittance.

speech.speaker: TIMON
speech.line: Ladies! what are their wills?

speech.speaker: Servant
speech.line: There comes with them a forerunner, my lord, which
bears that office, to signify their pleasures.

speech.speaker: TIMON
speech.line: I pray, let them be admitted.

speech.speaker: Cupid
speech.line: Hail to thee, worthy Timon, and to all
That of his bounties taste! The five best senses
Acknowledge thee their patron; and come freely
To gratulate thy plenteous bosom: th' ear,
Taste, touch and smell, pleased from thy tale rise;
They only now come but to feast thine eyes.

speech.speaker: TIMON
speech.line: They're welcome all; let 'em have kind admittance:
Music, make their welcome!

speech.speaker: First Lord
speech.line: You see, my lord, how ample you're beloved.

scene-body.stagedir: Music. Re-enter Cupid with a mask of Ladies as Amazons, with lutes in their hands, dancing and playing

speech.speaker: APEMANTUS
speech.line: Hoy-day, what a sweep of vanity comes this way!
They dance! they are mad women.
Like madness is the glory of this life.
As this pomp shows to a little oil and root.
We make ourselves fools, to disport ourselves;
And spend our flatteries, to drink those men
Upon whose age we void it up again,
With poisonous spite and envy.
Who lives that's not depraved or depraves?
Who dies, that bears not one spurn to their graves
Of their friends' gift?
I should fear those that dance before me now
Would one day stamp upon me: 't has been done;
Men shut their doors against a setting sun.

scene-body.stagedir: The Lords rise from table, with much adoring of TIMON; and to show their loves, each singles out an Amazon, and all dance, men with women, a lofty strain or two to the hautboys, and cease

speech.speaker: TIMON
speech.line: You have done our pleasures much grace, fair ladies,
Set a fair fashion on our entertainment,
Which was not half so beautiful and kind;
You have added worth unto 't and lustre,
And entertain'd me with mine own device;
I am to thank you for 't.

speech.speaker: First Lady
speech.line: My lord, you take us even at the best.

speech.speaker: APEMANTUS
speech.line: 'Faith, for the worst is filthy; and would not hold
taking, I doubt me.

speech.speaker: TIMON
speech.line: Ladies, there is an idle banquet attends you:
Please you to dispose yourselves.

speech.speaker: All Ladies
speech.line: Most thankfully, my lord.

speech.speaker: TIMON
speech.line: Flavius.

speech.speaker: FLAVIUS
speech.line: My lord?

speech.speaker: TIMON
speech.line: The little casket bring me hither.

speech.speaker: FLAVIUS
speech.line: Yes, my lord. More jewels yet!
There is no crossing him in 's humour;
Else I should tell him,--well, i' faith I should,
When all's spent, he 'ld be cross'd then, an he could.
'Tis pity bounty had not eyes behind,
That man might ne'er be wretched for his mind.

speech.speaker: First Lord
speech.line: Where be our men?

speech.speaker: Servant
speech.line: Here, my lord, in readiness.

speech.speaker: Second Lord
speech.line: Our horses!

speech.speaker: TIMON
speech.line: O my friends,
I have one word to say to you: look you, my good lord,
I must entreat you, honour me so much
As to advance this jewel; accept it and wear it,
Kind my lord.

speech.speaker: First Lord
speech.line: I am so far already in your gifts,--

speech.speaker: All
speech.line: So are we all.

speech.speaker: Servant
speech.line: My lord, there are certain nobles of the senate
Newly alighted, and come to visit you.

speech.speaker: TIMON
speech.line: They are fairly welcome.

speech.speaker: FLAVIUS
speech.line: I beseech your honour,
Vouchsafe me a word; it does concern you near.

speech.speaker: TIMON
speech.line: Near! why then, another time I'll hear thee:
I prithee, let's be provided to show them
entertainment.

speech.speaker: FLAVIUS
speech.line: Aside I scarce know how.

speech.speaker: Second Servant
speech.line: May it please your honour, Lord Lucius,
Out of his free love, hath presented to you
Four milk-white horses, trapp'd in silver.

speech.speaker: TIMON
speech.line: I shall accept them fairly; let the presents
Be worthily entertain'd.
How now! what news?

speech.speaker: Third Servant
speech.line: Please you, my lord, that honourable
gentleman, Lord Lucullus, entreats your company
to-morrow to hunt with him, and has sent your honour
two brace of greyhounds.

speech.speaker: TIMON
speech.line: I'll hunt with him; and let them be received,
Not without fair reward.

speech.speaker: FLAVIUS
speech.line: Aside What will this come to?
He commands us to provide, and give great gifts,
And all out of an empty coffer:
Nor will he know his purse, or yield me this,
To show him what a beggar his heart is,
Being of no power to make his wishes good:
His promises fly so beyond his state
That what he speaks is all in debt; he owes
For every word: he is so kind that he now
Pays interest for 't; his land's put to their books.
Well, would I were gently put out of office
Before I were forced out!
Happier is he that has no friend to feed
Than such that do e'en enemies exceed.
I bleed inwardly for my lord.

speech.speaker: TIMON
speech.line: You do yourselves
Much wrong, you bate too much of your own merits:
Here, my lord, a trifle of our love.

speech.speaker: Second Lord
speech.line: With more than common thanks I will receive it.

speech.speaker: Third Lord
speech.line: O, he's the very soul of bounty!

speech.speaker: TIMON
speech.line: And now I remember, my lord, you gave
Good words the other day of a bay courser
I rode on: it is yours, because you liked it.

speech.speaker: Second Lord
speech.line: O, I beseech you, pardon me, my lord, in that.

speech.speaker: TIMON
speech.line: You may take my word, my lord; I know, no man
Can justly praise but what he does affect:
I weigh my friend's affection with mine own;
I'll tell you true. I'll call to you.

speech.speaker: All Lords
speech.line: O, none so welcome.

speech.speaker: TIMON
speech.line: I take all and your several visitations
So kind to heart, 'tis not enough to give;
Methinks, I could deal kingdoms to my friends,
And ne'er be weary. Alcibiades,
Thou art a soldier, therefore seldom rich;
It comes in charity to thee: for all thy living
Is 'mongst the dead, and all the lands thou hast
Lie in a pitch'd field.

speech.speaker: ALCIBIADES
speech.line: Ay, defiled land, my lord.

speech.speaker: First Lord
speech.line: We are so virtuously bound--

speech.speaker: TIMON
speech.line: And so
Am I to you.

speech.speaker: Second Lord
speech.line: So infinitely endear'd--

speech.speaker: TIMON
speech.line: All to you. Lights, more lights!

speech.speaker: First Lord
speech.line: The best of happiness,
Honour and fortunes, keep with you, Lord Timon!

speech.speaker: TIMON
speech.line: Ready for his friends.

scene-body.stagedir: Exeunt all but APEMANTUS and TIMON

speech.speaker: APEMANTUS
speech.line: What a coil's here!
Serving of becks and jutting-out of bums!
I doubt whether their legs be worth the sums
That are given for 'em. Friendship's full of dregs:
Methinks, false hearts should never have sound legs,
Thus honest fools lay out their wealth on court'sies.

speech.speaker: TIMON
speech.line: Now, Apemantus, if thou wert not sullen, I would be
good to thee.

speech.speaker: APEMANTUS
speech.line: No, I'll nothing: for if I should be bribed too,
there would be none left to rail upon thee, and then
thou wouldst sin the faster. Thou givest so long,
Timon, I fear me thou wilt give away thyself in
paper shortly: what need these feasts, pomps and
vain-glories?

speech.speaker: TIMON
speech.line: Nay, an you begin to rail on society once, I am
sworn not to give regard to you. Farewell; and come
with better music.

speech.speaker: APEMANTUS
speech.line: So:
Thou wilt not hear me now; thou shalt not then:
I'll lock thy heaven from thee.
O, that men's ears should be
To counsel deaf, but not to flattery!
